description.narrative: China’s Protected Area Reform (C-PAR) for Conserving Globally Significant Biodiversity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: Indicator 2: National terrestrial PA system expanded, with an emphasis on habitat connectivity and increasing coverage of KBAs among the three NP pilot sites of Three-River Source NP (TRS NP); Giant Panda NP (GP NP); and Xianju NP (XJ NP)

comment.narrative:
Baseline: Estimates of direct beneficiaries based on a capacity building needs assessment and stakeholder consultations during the PPG phase. These estimates will be verified at project inception through development of the capacity development plan for the C-PAR program and confirmation consultations with villages where project interventions are planned.
Baseline: Cumulative size of national terrestrial protected area system: 162.44 million ha, 2016 (16.9% of total land area)

Output 1.1 Strengthened legal and governance framework for the national park system, with NP system guideline and regulations, mainstreamed into land-use planning and ecological redlining Output 1.2 National gap and connectivity analysis and advanced policies and guidelines developed for effective expansion and management of the NP system. Output 1.3 Institutional enabling environment strengthened through introduction of PA competency based standards and delivery of training to key central change agents. Output 1.4 Sustainability of PA financing strengthened through policy and demonstrations of diversification of funding sources, improved efficiency in access and utilisation of available funds, broadened participation through concession arrangements and value-based eco-compensation appropriations. Output 2.1 Dynamic conservation planning, NP regulations, and collaborative governance arrangements for NP system pilot implementation. Output 2.2 Institutional capacities of NP pilot management agencies through implementation of PA competency standards, introduction of international best practices, implementation of technical guidelines and strengthened partnerships. Output 2.3 Community benefits strengthened through demonstration of collaborative management arrangements, including implementation of human wildlife conflict management plans, tourism partnerships and concessions, and environmental education programs. Output 3.1 Effective project management and program coordination supported through proactive steering committee functions, an aggregated reporting mechanism and inclusive monitoring & evaluation. Output 3.2 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system. Output 3.3 Dynamic biodiversity knowledge platform operationalised, providing a unified system for knowledge sharing, uptake of best practices and broader participation Output 3.4 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system.

1. Legal, governance and institutional framework Nine study achievements had an active effect on National Parks (NPs) legislation, Protected Area (PA) polices about Human-wildlife Conflict (HWC), technical guidelines of NP concessions, technical contributions of PA networks to climate change, technical estimates for biodiversity conservation financing and technical standards of enhancing institutional capacities. a) Study on Roadmap and Framework of National Park Law of China b) HWC management study c) Study on PA Network Layout and Ecological Corridors under the Climate Change d) Guidelines and A Case Study on Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) e) Competency-based Standards for PA Professional Development f) Knowledge Transfer and Online Training g) Study on the National Park Concessions in China h) A comparative analysis of performance of existing PA financing programs and mechanisms in China i) NP Green Fund and Social Donation System Study 2. Pilot Development By Nov.30, 2021, the outcome goes as scheduled in TRS and Giant Panda (GP) NP system pilots. 71%, 83% and 42% activities were ongoing in TRS NP system pilot, GP NP system pilot and Xianju (XJ) NP pilot, respectively. These activities included training, evaluations and other relevant improvements, which enhanced institutional capacities and paved way for future work. 3. Management, M&E and Public Sharing a) The project management and program coordination were strengthened and all work was pushed as planned with a steady and effective PMO team. It will provide a platform for effective communication in the future. b) The outcomes of the C-PAR program were disseminated in the COP15, which received plenty of positive feedback. c) The promote products are more diverse than ever. Especially, the knowledge management platform started in the procurement process. In the coming year, it will be largely conductive to raise public awareness and increase the impact of the project. d) The Social and Environmental Safeguards (SES) risks were curbed by conducting Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) and Environmental and Social Management Plan (ESMP), which is vital to decrease social risks and ensure the process of the projects.

Output 1.1 Strengthened legal and governance framework for the national park system, with NP system guideline and regulations, mainstreamed into land-use planning and ecological redlining Output 1.2 National gap and connectivity analysis and advanced policies and guidelines developed for effective expansion and management of the NP system. Output 1.3 Institutional enabling environment strengthened through introduction of PA competency based standards and delivery of training to key central change agents. Output 1.4 Sustainability of PA financing strengthened through policy and demonstrations of diversification of funding sources, improved efficiency in access and utilisation of available funds, broadened participation through concession arrangements and value-based eco-compensation appropriations. Output 2.1 Dynamic conservation planning, NP regulations, and collaborative governance arrangements for NP system pilot implementation. Output 2.2 Institutional capacities of NP pilot management agencies through implementation of PA competency standards, introduction of international best practices, implementation of technical guidelines and strengthened partnerships. Output 2.3 Community benefits strengthened through demonstration of collaborative management arrangements, including implementation of human wildlife conflict management plans, tourism partnerships and concessions, and environmental education programs. Output 3.1 Effective project management and program coordination supported through proactive steering committee functions, an aggregated reporting mechanism and inclusive monitoring & evaluation. Output 3.2 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system. Output 3.3 Dynamic biodiversity knowledge platform operationalised, providing a unified system for knowledge sharing, uptake of best practices and broader participation Output 3.4 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system.

The 5th Plenary Session of the 19th Central Committee emphasized to promote the National Park (NP) and Protected Areas (PA) legislation and governance. In 2020, two studies were conducted to strengthen the legal and governance framework for the national park (NP) system. One is “Study on Roadmap and Framework of National Park Law of China” and just started. From the top-level design to concrete solution, the study will give suggestions to National Forestry and Grassland Administration (NFGA) on the relationships between the Protected Area Law and the National Park Law, the key issues in the legislation process of the National Park Law, the lessons learned in the related laws and system barriers in NP system pilots. This will push the legislation of the National Park Law towards the Guidance on Establishing a Protected Area System with National Parks as the Backbone (2019); Another is “Environmental Analysis and Countermeasure Study on Hydroelectric and Mining Projects in the Protected Areas (PA)”. It was completed in 6 months and proposed an Environmental Impact Assessment Index System (3 quantitative indexes) and first proposed 3 mechanisms (exit mechanism, management mechanism and compensation mechanism) to supervise the hydroelectric and mining projects, which provided MEE with governance countermeasure on hydroelectric and mining projects in the national Protected Areas (PA). This effectively supported the related work of MEE and NFGA.

Output 1.1 Strengthened legal and governance framework for the national park system, with NP system guideline and regulations, mainstreamed into land-use planning and ecological redlining Output 1.2 National gap and connectivity analysis and advanced policies and guidelines developed for effective expansion and management of the NP system. Output 1.3 Institutional enabling environment strengthened through introduction of PA competency based standards and delivery of training to key central change agents. Output 1.4 Sustainability of PA financing strengthened through policy and demonstrations of diversification of funding sources, improved efficiency in access and utilisation of available funds, broadened participation through concession arrangements and value-based eco-compensation appropriations. Output 2.1 Dynamic conservation planning, NP regulations, and collaborative governance arrangements for NP system pilot implementation. Output 2.2 Institutional capacities of NP pilot management agencies through implementation of PA competency standards, introduction of international best practices, implementation of technical guidelines and strengthened partnerships. Output 2.3 Community benefits strengthened through demonstration of collaborative management arrangements, including implementation of human wildlife conflict management plans, tourism partnerships and concessions, and environmental education programs. Output 3.1 Effective project management and program coordination supported through proactive steering committee functions, an aggregated reporting mechanism and inclusive monitoring & evaluation. Output 3.2 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system. Output 3.4 C-PAR knowledge management strategy developed and implemented, supporting raised awareness of decision makers and the public on the values of the national park system.

Under the strong guidance and support of the Ministry of Finance (MOF), Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) and UNDP, the Project Document was signed by UNDP, MOF and FECO on March 8, 2019. With the joint efforts of UNDP and FECO, the Project Management Office (PMO) was established in July, 2019 and four full-time staff and a part-time Chief Technical Advisor (CTA) were recruited. In general, the project implementation has made progress and all activities and tasks of 2019 were completed.
The budget for 2019 is US$85,321, with expenditure accounting to US$84,658 until Dec. 31, 2019 and the delivery rate of the project in 2019 reaches 99%. During the reporting period, the main achievements of the project are as follows: (i) The partnership for Protected Area (PA) and National Park (NP) reform was established. (ii) The official launch of the GEF C-PAR program was announced. (iii) The communication mechanism among child-projects at programme level was established. (iv) Preparation for the project inception workshop was completed on time.
